title: Arthritis and Acupuncture
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors
description: WebMD examines acupuncture and how it is used to relieve arthritis and other chronic pain.
cleaned_text: What Is Acupuncture and How Does It Work? It's a form of traditional Chinese medicine. It aims to correct imbalances of energy, or "chi," in the body. To do that, practitioners use very fine stainless-steel needles to stimulate the body's 14 major energy-carrying channels, or "meridians." [Acupuncture](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/consider-acupuncture) may curb [pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/default.htm) by boosting the amount of natural pain killers your body makes, called endorphins. What Conditions Might It Help Treat? [Acupuncture](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/ss/slideshow-acupuncture-overview) may be part of treatment for [chronic pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/ss/slideshow-chronic-pain-myths-facts), such as: [Arthritis](https://www.webmd.com/arthritis/video/rippe-arthritis-any-age) - Low back, neck, or [muscle pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/guide/myofascial-pain-syndrome) - Pain after surgery Some studies have shown it to be an effective treatment for: - Dental pain [Fibromyalgia](https://www.webmd.com/fibromyalgia/default.htm) [Nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting)from [chemotherapy](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/chemotherapy-what-to-expect) More studies are needed to see how well it works for [headaches](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/default.htm), pain from [shingles](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/shingles/default.htm), facial pain, and as an aid to [quit smoking](https://www.webmd.com/smoking-cessation/default.htm). You shouldn't rely on acupuncture to treat a chronic or serious illness unless you see a doctor first. Acupuncture may not be the best way to improve your condition. Or it could be OK for you, but it doesn't replace other medical care, such as [physical therapy](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/tc/physical-therapy-topic-overview) or [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx). For certain conditions, such as [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/default.htm), you should get acupuncture only in combination with other treatments. What Happens During a Session The person who treats you is called an acupuncturist. They'll swab each area with alcohol before tapping a very thin needle into the site. The number of needles you'll get, where they're placed, and how deeply they're inserted depends upon your particular case. The needles will stay in place for several minutes to an hour. The acupuncturist may adjust, warm, or electrically energize them to intensify the effect. You may feel some tingling if electricity is used. It should be mild, and you can ask your acupuncturist to dial it down at any time. You may need to get more than one session. Does Acupuncture Hurt? No. You may feel a slight prick when the needle is inserted, but it is much less than the prick you feel during a shot, since the needles are much thinner. You may feel a heaviness, numbness, tingling, or mild soreness after the needles have been put in. Is It Safe? Yes. When acupuncture is done with disposable needles under clean, sterile conditions, and by a qualified practitioner, complications are very unlikely. What Are the Advantages of It? It's a drug-free way to ease pain. You can't get addicted to it. And the acupuncturist can immediately see how you respond and make any changes as needed. Does the Medical Establishment Approve of It? Yes. There are about 28,000 licensed acupuncturists in the U.S. The FDA also sees acupuncture needles as medical devices. Will My Health Insurance Policy Cover It? Some [insurance](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-health-insurance-basics) companies will pay for this treatment. So check with your plan. How Often Should I Get Acupuncture? It depends on your condition and how well it works for you. Because it may take several sessions before you feel a benefit, plan to go at least 5-10 times. Are There Any Restrictions on What I Can Do After a Treatment? You'll probably feel really relaxed, because acupuncture can be very calming. So you might want to have someone who can take you home. If you feel great after your session, you still need to pace yourself so you don't try to do too much, too soon. You should keep taking any medicines your doctor prescribed, too.
